universalSymptomDescription: Dyspnoea refers to the subjective sensation of shortness of breath. It should be differentiated from an increased work of breathing or a rapid rate of breathing (tachypnoea) which are objective signs seen by a healthcare professional, although they often occur together.

causes: LV dysfunction (systolic or diastolic) leading to pulmonary oedema
Structural heart disease e.g. cardiomyopathies, congenital
Obstructive disease e.g. asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis
Neuromuscular and skeletal e.g. motor neurone disease
Obesity hypoventilation and obstructive sleep apnoea
Laryngeal obstruction e.g. foreign body, laryngeal oedema, laryngospasm
Metabolic acidosis (Kussmaul's respiration) e.g. in diabetic ketoacidosis

universalSymptomDescription: There are many causes of chest pain. A careful history is required to differentiate the serious from benign causes. A useful mnemonic is SOCRATES = site, onset, character, radiation, associated features, timing, exacerbating and relieving factors, severity. Cardiac chest pain is central and is often described as a tightness, heaviness or pressure. It is usually worse on exertion and commonly radiates to the shoulders, left arm, jaw or teeth. It is associated with nausea/vomiting and diaphoresis. It is relieved by rest or nitrates.

causes: Ischaemic heart disease (acute and chronic coronary syndromes)
Non-atherosclerotic disease e.g. vasospasm, embolic events, microvascular disease, dissection
Pleural e.g. pneumothorax, effusion, pleuritis (Bornholm disease)

universalSymptomDescription: Syncope refers to a transient loss of consciousness due to a sudden global reduction of blood supply to the brain. There is typically a rapid recovery. Syncope should be differentiated from other causes of loss of consciousness such as seizures and hypoglycaemia. Syncope may be preceded presyncope (the feeling that one may faint).

causes: Arrhythmias e.g. ventricular tachycardia or bradycardias
Obstructive lesions e.g. aortic stenosis, HCM or acute pulmonary embolism
Vasovagal syncope (simple faint) e.g. physical or emotional stressor, dehydration
Autonomic dysfunction e.g. diabetes, Parkinson’s disease
Drugs e.g. antihypertensives, diuretics, beta blockers, antipsychotics

universalSymptomDescription: Presyncope refers to the sensation of feeling like one is about to faint. It usually consists of light-headedness, sweatiness, blackening of vision and feeling weakness in the arms and legs. It has similar causes to syncope. It should be differentiated from other causes of ‘dizziness’ such as vertigo (the sensation that the environment is spinning/moving).

causes: Arrhythmias e.g. ventricular tachycardia or bradycardias
Obstructive lesions e.g. aortic stenosis, HCM or acute pulmonary embolism
Vasovagal reflex e.g. physical or emotional stressor, dehydration
Autonomic dysfunction e.g. diabetes, Parkinson’s disease
Drugs e.g. antihypertensives, diuretics, beta blockers, antipsychotics

universalSymptomDescription: Palpitations are an increased awareness of one’s heartbeat. Patients typically describe feeling their heart ‘fluttering’, ‘racing’, ‘skipping a beat’ or ‘pounding’ in their chest. Patients often experience palpitations in the absence of significant cardiac arrhythmias.

Pedal oedema refers to swelling of the feet, ankles and legs due to peripheral fluid accumulation in the tissues. Pedal oedema due to cardiac and fluid oncotic pressure abnormalities is bilateral and pitting in nature. Lymphoedema produces both pitting and non-pitting oedema.

causes: Right-sided valve lesions e.g. tricuspid regurgitation

universalSymptomDescription: Ascites is the accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity. It can result in abdominal distention and abdominal pain. It is a relatively rare presentation of cardiac disease and other causes should be sought in the first instance. Ascites due to cardiac and fluid oncotic pressure abnormalities is transudative. Ascites due to inflammatory processes is exudative.

causes: Right-sided valve disease e.g. tricuspid regurgitation
Liver cirrhosis (multifactorial: portal hypertension, secondary hyperaldosteronism and hypoalbuminaemia)
Liver cirrhosis (multifactorial: portal hypertension, secondary hyperaldosteronism and hypoalbuminaemia)

universalSymptomDescription: Failure to thrive is a term used to refer to children who are not gaining sufficient weight or growing in an expected manner. It has many causes, including both organic and, more commonly, non-organic (due to failure of caregivers to provide sufficient caloric intake).

causes: Food allergies e.g. cow’s milk protein allergy

universalSymptomDescription: Central cyanosis describes a blue-purple discolouration of the lips, face and torso. It is caused by a decrease in arterial oxygen saturation (i.e. an increase in arterial deoxygenated haemoglobin). It is almost always indicative of underlying disease. It should be differentiated from peripheral cyanosis, which describes discolouration of the fingertips and nail beds and is caused by a decrease in venous oxygen saturations in the peripheries due to tissue utilisation. It is most commonly caused by peripheral vasoconstriction (e.g. in cold weather).

causes: Cyanotic congenital heart disease (e.g. Tetralogy of Fallot)
Extra-cardiac shunts e.g. pulmonary arteriovenous malformation
Obstructive disease e.g. asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis
Obesity hypoventilation and obstructive sleep apnoea

universalSymptomDescription: Sudden cardiac death (SCD) is death from a cardiac cause that occurs unexpectedly and suddenly. The direct cause is usually a non-perfusing cardiac arrhythmia such as pulseless ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation. If the patient receives effective resuscitation during their cardiac arrest, sudden cardiac death may be aborted, but significant morbidity may result.

causes: Embolic coronary events (e.g. infective endocarditis, LV thrombus, AF
